title: Planning for the pollock assessment in the EBS
text: SSC suggests walleye pollock good candidate considering impacts highly variable recruitment reference points context Council’s harvest control rules (see discussion working groups JGPT report section). example, SAFE authors suggested exploring explicit harvest control rule maintains productivity level observed recent decades (p. 33). SSC supports considerations modified harvest control rules, particularly stocks highly variable uncertain recruitment. Council chooses, include considerations stabilizing catches time including economic considerations harvest control rules. 2023 assessment examine variability biological reference points historically note general stability \(B_{MSY}\) estimates. Tier 1 ABC/OFL cthealculations can result highly variable estimates stock approaches \(B_{MSY}\) drops value (happend 2009-2010 period). SSC following additional recommendations authors: Maturity growth information NBS examined yet. Given possible importance NBS walleye pollock species future, SSC suggests high priority. data processed work underway SSC supports efforts implement recent advances improving statistical treatment compositional data using Dirichlet distribution approaches. Tradeoffs data weighting pursued September 2023 saught find balance observation error process errors SAFE document lists number research recommendations (p. 36/37). SSC notes least progress. SSC generally supports recommendations requests authors update list priorities clarify extent priorities partially fully addressed. updated priorities listed completed continued underway” particular, SSC notes genetic sample collection analyses listed research priority across pollock stocks work completed. SSC highlights importance additional genetics work appreciate update status work either part assessment separately. revisited stock structure work attached appendix 2015 SAFE report chapter examining extent work needs updating. ” SSC appreciated adjustments weight--age survey included year’s assessment suggests changes may substantial enough warrant examination impact assessment results. publication completed present assessment evaluated implication alternative spawning biomass--age assumptions.” respect multi-species CEATTLE model, SSC concurs Plan Team recommendations use model inform risk table discussions consider ways model outputs, particular estimates predation mortality, can inform single-species assessments. wil include thorough evaluation discussion 2023 assessment. SSC encourages authors consider model-based solutions uncertain recruitment estimates rather ad-hoc adjustments. particular, reductions assumed recruitment variance parameter may result less extreme recruitment estimates. systematic approaches addressing uncertainty may also considered. revisited applying age-determination error matrix sensitivity can impact recruitment variability estimation uncertainty. SSC suggests authors include plot compare estimates recent recruitments change time similar Fig 3.33 (pg. 88) sablefish assessment. provide figure estimated recruitment year class (1977 – 2019) number age-1 fish (billions fish) 2022 2023 models. ” SSC supports move across assessment design-based estimates survey biomass VAST estimates. SSC recommends design-based estimates produced check VAST estimates fallback option needed, although may need included assessment. provide table showing design-based estimates conduct model run estimates. may approach adopt bridging across assessment modeling platforms can facilitated (assessment model platforms unable deal index time series covariance matrix)

title: Planning for the pollock assessment in the EBS

title: Planning for the pollock assessment in the EBS
text: Ongoing genetic studies determine relationship pollock NBS EBS, nearby GOA AI regions. 2019 BSAI GPT recommendation revisit evaluate treatment variance parameters within assessment, particular attention fixed. Efforts quantify pollock movement abundance along US-Russia EEZ boundary. Geostatistical analyses combined trawl acoustic data provide single time-series, statistically accounting overlap data, informing stock trends.

what: The SSC provides the following additional recommendations:
title: Planning for the pollock assessment in the EBS
text: Exploration young--year pollock density quality estimates NMFS BASIS surveys inform pollock recruitment. Consideration whether observed sensitivity SRR prior specification constitute increased risk level specification within assessment population dynamicsrelated considerations. provide clearer justification use Tier 3 calculation basis harvest specification. Given time-varying specification fishery selectivity within assessment model large change estimated 2021 FOFL 2019 2020 assessments, authors provide retrospective comparison selectivity assumed projections estimated addition new data. Consideration whether risk table specifications account importance pollock key forage species EBS ecosystem better justify use Tier 3 ABC determination precautionary measure Tier 1 stock. Given apparent disappearance second large mode fishery length compositions 2020 B-season progressed, exploration within-season spatial variation fishery length composition useful evaluating whether larger pollock simply moved area fishing effort, died result natural fishing mortality.

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
title: Example on how to change and run a model
text: Now use avon2 file fix vales “ssb” files
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_avon2.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_ssb0.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/pm_ssb0new.dat", tmp=d3)  # Create directory and copy key files dir.create("runs/ssb0") file.copy("runs/avon2/control.dat","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.copy("runs/avon2/compweights.ctl","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.remove("runs/ssb0/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/ssb0/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/avon2/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   row.names(pm.dat) <- c("Desc","main","sel","ctl","altFmsy","cov","wtage","cpue","temp","q")   pm.dat   pm.dat[1,] <- "Updated_SSB0_to_avon2"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/pm_ssb0new.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/ssb0/pm.dat")

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_avon2.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_ssb1.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/pm_ssb1new.dat", tmp=d3)  # Create directory and copy key files dir.create("runs/ssb1") file.copy("runs/avon2/control.dat","runs/ssb1/",overwrite = TRUE) file.copy("runs/avon2/compweights.ctl","runs/ssb1/",overwrite = TRUE) file.remove("runs/ssb1/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/ssb1/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/avon2/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   pm.dat[1,] <- "Updated_SSB1_to_avon2"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/pm_ssb1new.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/ssb1/pm.dat")

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_avon2.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_ssb2.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/pm_ssb2new.dat", tmp=d3)  # Create directory and copy key files dir.create("runs/ssb2") file.copy("runs/avon2/control.dat","runs/ssb2/",overwrite = TRUE) file.copy("runs/avon2/compweights.ctl","runs/ssb2/",overwrite = TRUE) file.remove("runs/ssb2/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/ssb2/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/avon2/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   pm.dat[1,] <- "Updated_SSB2_to_avon2"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/pm_ssb2new.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/ssb2/pm.dat")

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
what: Now run them all in parallel
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: mod_dir   <- c("avon2","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   mod_names <- c("avon2","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   # Need to make output=TRUE default, also check on spm   ssbres <- run_model(Output=TRUE)   ssbres <- get_results()   ssbres[[1]]   tab_fit(ssbres, mod_scen = c(1:3)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(ssbres, mod_scen = c(1:3)) |> gt::gt()      # See if different from base   tail(sc2)   ctl <-read_dat("runs/ProcTune/control.dat")   ctlb <-read_dat("runs/base22/control.dat")   diff <- purrr::map_lgl(names(ctl), ~ !identical(ctl[[.]], ctlb[[.]]))   sum(diff)   names(ctl[diff])   cbind(ctl[diff][2],ctlb[diff][2])   names(ctl)   ctl[56]   write_dat("runs/base22/control.dat",ctl)  # Set an initial working directory   mod_names <- c("AVON Full","Proc_tune")   mod_dir <- c("avon2", "ProcTune")   # Note, 0.2 CV for selectivity variability nails it (from base22)   # Read, adjust, write...   sc <-read_table("runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col_names = FALSE); names(sc) <- c("Year","fsh","bts","ats")   tail(sc )   # Iterated on selectivity   sc2 <-  sc |> mutate(ats = ifelse(ats>0,.138,0))   write.table(sc2,file="runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col.names = FALSE,row.names = FALSE)   #modtune <- run_model(Output=TRUE)   modtune<-get_results()   tab_fit(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modlst, mod_scen = c(4,5)) |> gt::gt()   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssbs)   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssb.sd)   (modtune[[1]]$nextyrssbs)   names(modtune)

what: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: R package ebswp developed stock assessments eastern Bering Sea walleye pollock AFSC. stock assessment model coded using Autodif Model Builder (ADMB) software.

code: devtools::install_github(repo = "afsc-assessments/ebswp", dependencies = TRUE,                           build_vignettes = TRUE, auth_token = "your_PAT")

title: sbt
text: R package sbt developed stock assessments southern bluefin tuna (SBT) Comission Conservation Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT). stock assessment model coded using Template Model Builder (TMB) software. operating model (OM) age structured model. Frequentist inference can done using nlminb Bayesian inference can done using R package tmbstan.

title: sbt
text: R package sbt lives private GitHub repository. repository can cloned computer command line using user interface. command line using Linux repository can cloned using: sbt repository private, prompted enter username personal access token (PAT).

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: function generates series plots visualizing age composition data fisheries assessment. compares observed predicted data across different years.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
code: plot_agefit(   x,   case_label = "2021 assessment",   gear = "bts",   type = "survey",   styr = NULL,   ageplus = NULL )

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: case_label Label specific case dataset visualized. Default "2011 assessment". dat data frame, default mod1. structure must contain age composition data, names used create temporary variables tmp1, tmp2, tmp3. main Title main plot. Default empty string. f integer representing fishery index. Default 1. rec_age integer denoting recruitment age. Default 2.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: multi-panel plot panel visualizes age composition data specific year.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: function plots observed fishery age composition data using bar plot, overlaying predicted data points. organizes plots multi-panel figure, panel representing year. Age classes represented x-axis.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: function uses rainbow color palette, colors loop around cohort. function expects certain naming conventions input dataset dat.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
code: # Example usage (ensure you have an appropriate dataset 'mod1'): # AgeFits(dat=mod1, main="Fishery Age Composition", case_label="Sample Assessment")

title: Plot Acoustic Trawl Survey Biomass Data — plot_ats

title: Plot Acoustic Trawl Survey Biomass Data — plot_ats
text: M List  model outputs. list object like one accepted .get_ats_df. xlab Label x-axis. Default "Year". ylab Label y-axis. Default "Acoustic trawl survey biomass". xlim Optional range x-axis. ylim Optional range y-axis. alpha Opacity ribbon, used. Default 0.1. biomass Logical flag. TRUE, plots data related biomass; FALSE, plots data related another metric. Default TRUE. color Color data points. Default "red".

title: Plot Acoustic Trawl Survey Biomass Data — plot_ats
text: ggplot2 plot object visualizing acoustic trawl survey data.

title: Plot Likelihood Values — plot_likes
text: function plots negative log likelihood values different components specified predictor (e.g., natural mortality). function uses ggplot2 visualization.

title: Plot Likelihood Values — plot_likes
code: plot_likes(   M,   xlab = "Natural Mortality",   ylab = "relative -ln Likelihood",   ylim = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   alpha = 0.1,   legend = TRUE )

title: Plot Likelihood Values — plot_likes
text: M list models likelihood values extracted. xlab Label x-axis. Default "Natural Mortality". ylab Label y-axis. Default "relative -ln Likelihood". ylim Limits y-axis. Default NULL. xlim Limits x-axis. Default NULL. alpha Alpha transparency level plotted lines. Default 0.1. legend Logical indicating whether display legend. Default TRUE.

title: Plot Likelihood Values — plot_likes
text: ggplot object displaying negative log likelihood values.

title: Plot Likelihood Values — plot_likes
code: # Assuming 'model_list' is a list of models with the appropriate structure # plot_likes(model_list)

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: function plots stock-recruitment relationship (SRR) using ggplot2. can handle multiple models provides flexibility display options.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
code: plot_srr(   M,   ylab = "Recruits (age 1, millions)",   xlab = "Female spawning biomass (kt)",   ylim = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   ebar = "FALSE",   leglabs = NULL,   coverlap = FALSE,   sizein = 3,   sizeout = 2,   yrsin = 1977:2019 )

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: M list data structure containing model results. ylab Label y-axis. Default "Recruits (age 1, millions)". xlab Label x-axis. Default "Female spawning biomass (kt)". ylim Limits y-axis. Default NULL. xlim Limits x-axis. Default NULL. alpha Alpha ribbons indicating uncertainty. Default 0.05. ebar Logical, TRUE error bars plotted. Default FALSE. leglabs Custom labels legend. Default NULL. coverlap Logical, TRUE overlapping text labels checked prevented. Default FALSE. sizein Font size -sample text labels. Default 3. sizeout Font size --sample text labels. Default 2. yrsin Years considered -sample. Default 1977:2019.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: ggplot object containing SRR plot.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
code: # Assuming 'model_list' contains the relevant model results: # plot_srr(M = model_list, ylim = c(0, 1e6), xlim = c(0, 2000))
